Water Quality and Summary Statistics

Lesson Objective: In this lesson, you will learn how to use the Python programming language to calculate summary statistics and investigate water quality samples.

Materials Needed:
- Your computer
- A web browser (e.g., Chrome, Firefox, Safari)
- Handout ??

Facilitator/Teacher Resources:

Link to Facilitator‚Äôs Guide

üî¨üíß Welcome, Scientists!

Over the next several weeks, we will work together to understand the water in our community, its importance, nutrients, and how we can protect it.

We will use aspects of computing and programming, statistics, and environmental and agricultural science to learn more about local waterways. In today‚Äôs lesson, we will consider the role of pH in our water, how we measure it, analyze it, and consider its role in water quality and local ecosystems.

Never used programming before? Perfect! This module is designed for complete beginners. We‚Äôll learn everything step by step.

üêç What is Python?

Python is a programming language ‚Äî a way to give instructions to a computer. Think of it like writing a recipe, but for the computer!

Why Python?
- Scientists use it to analyze data
- It can do math way faster than we can
- It can create beautiful graphs

Don‚Äôt worry! You don‚Äôt need to install anything. You can run Python code right here in your web browser!

üíª Let‚Äôs Try Python Right Now!

Text/Strings

Python will print text.

Click the ‚ñ∂Ô∏è button below to run your first Python code:

üéâ You just ran Python code! See how it printed ‚ÄúHello, Water Scientist!‚Äù below the block? We call text printed like this a string.

Notice that strings must be in quotation marks within the code but those marks don‚Äôt appear when printed. The quotation marks just tell the computer ‚ÄúHey! I‚Äôm writing regular text. Treat it like written English instead of code.,‚Äù and it does!
